Fig. 1 Top view of Co and Co-BaO model catalysts. Surfaces were constructed from 4 × 6 supercells of the Co (10 1 ¯ 5) surface, involving four-atomic layers. Co atoms in the B5 sites are highlighted. Color code: Co (pink), B5 site (purple), Ba (green) and O (red). Adapted with permission from [31]. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 Gibbs free energies of N, NH3, H, H2O and O absorbed on Co and Co-BaO at 723.15 K. Energies are relative to the bare surface and NH3(g), H2(g) and H2O(g). The configurations of the adsorbates are provided in Table S2. Fig. 3 Gibbs free energy reaction profile of water dissociation on Co and Co-BaO at 723.15 K. Energies are relative to the bare surface, H2O(g) and H2(g). The labels assigned to each step denote the corresponding reacting species. The values of all the energy barriers and the structures of the transition states are shown in Table S4. Fig. 4 Steady state surface coverage distributions of reaction species for (a) Co and (b) Co-BaO at 723.15 K. Initially, the surface was treated as empty, assuming a zero-coverage state for all species. The net surface coverage is determined by reaction kinetics, not just thermodynamics. Since Co-BaO has enhanced reduction kinetics, it maintains a lower *O coverage and more available free sites for the reaction. Feed composition is PH2O = 10-4 bar and initial PH2 = 5 × 10-6 bar. A small initial pressure was used to see the effect of increasing the PH2 gradually. The conversion of ammonia is based on the conditions of the ammonia decomposition reaction (initial 1 bar of NH3). Fig. 5 Surface coverage of oxygen (ML) versus ammonia conversion % for (a) Co and (b) Co-BaO at 723.15 K. PH2O = 0.01 bar was used. The conversion of ammonia is based on the conditions of the ammonia decomposition reaction (initial 1 bar of NH3). The coverage of oxygen decreases as the ammonia decomposition reaction proceeds. Research article Effect of water impurities on promoted and unpromoted cobalt-catalysts during the ammonia decomposition reaction Zahra Almisbaa Writing – original draft Investigation Conceptualization a Philippe Sautet Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization a b ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095, United States Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering University of California, Los Angeles Los Angeles CA 90095 United States Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095, United States b Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095, United States Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry University of California, Los Angeles Los Angeles CA 90095 United States Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095, United States ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA 90095, United States. Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering University of California, Los Angeles Los Angeles CA 90095 United States Graphical abstract The feedstock of the ammonia decomposition reaction often contains water impurities. Water-induced Co oxidation leads to catalyst deactivation. DFT-based microkinetic simulations of ammonia decomposition and water dissociation reactions are used to understand oxygen poisoning on promoted and unpromoted Co surfaces. Simulations show that catalyst oxidation only occurs at low NH3 conversion and, at higher conversion, the produced H2 reduces the catalyst. Hence, in a typical flow reactor, catalyst oxidation is likely to occur only at the reactor inlet. However, the oxidized zone can slowly propagate along the reactor and impact the catalyst stability. The adsorption of oxygen was stronger on BaO-promoted Co in comparison to pristine Co. However, Co-BaO is more sensitive to H2 pressure and needs a lower ammonia conversion to prevent oxygen poisoning on the surface. This indicates that the BaO promoter plays a role in making the catalyst more resistant to O-induced poisoning during the ammonia decomposition reaction. Keywords Ammonia decomposition Hydrogen carrier Water poisoning DFT Microkinetic simulation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Advancing hydrogen energy technologies requires developing efficient processes for ammonia decomposition. While the storage and the transport infrastructure of ammonia is well-established, generating hydrogen from ammonia is still in the early stages of development. Designing catalysts with enhanced resistance to poisoning from contaminants in the feed can further improve the process [1,2]. Therefore, it is of great interest to explore the catalyst properties that are relevant to commercial applications. Ruthenium-based catalysts are known to be the most active catalysts for the ammonia decomposition reaction [2–7]. However, the cost and scarcity of Ru restrict its adoption in the industry [3,7]. Cobalt-based catalysts are economically attractive alternatives with promising activity [6]. It was found that Ba-promoted Co performed similarly to the K-promoted Ru benchmark at temperatures as low as 450 °C [8,9]. Given the great potential of Co-based catalysts for commercial ammonia decomposition, further research is needed to better understand catalyst deactivation in the presence of feed impurities, as this aspect is still unexplored in the literature. The susceptibility of Co catalysts to water poisoning has been addressed in other catalytic processes such as ammonia synthesis and Fischer-Tropsch. Water leads to the adsorption of oxygen species which blocks the active sites and eventually leads to catalyst deactivation. Particularly, the step sites of Co surfaces exhibit significantly higher reactivity towards water dissociation compared to flat Co surfaces [10,11]. Also, the removal of adsorbed oxygen from the undercoordinated Co sites is challenging [12]. More importantly, occupying the step sites by water species, notably the B5 sites, poses a major risk as these sites are critical for N2 dissociation for ammonia synthesis [6,7,13]. For Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, the oxidation of the Co catalyst was found to be dependent on the partial pressure ratio of H2O to H2 (PH2O/PH2) [14]. This means that the appropriate (PH2O/PH2) and crystallite size can be used to prevent the oxidation of Co in the reactor [15]. In the case of the ammonia decomposition reaction, the reaction feedstock often contains some levels of water as impurities from ammonia synthesis [16]. Standard laboratory purification methods often fall short in preventing water contamination [17]. The catalyst acts as the most sensitive indicator of oxygen-containing impurities in the feed because it is challenging to perform experiments with high accuracy [17]. In addition, the different reaction conditions, feed composition, products, and the presence of promoters shape a unique challenge. The issue becomes more complicated with the presence of promoters on the catalytic surface. In the ammonia synthesis reaction, the effect of water poisoning was found to be more pronounced and O-containing species were more stabilized with the presence of K on the surface compared to K-free catalyts [18,19]. As promoters make catalysts more active, they also make them more susceptible to oxygen poisoning [18]. Nonetheless, the conditions for ammonia synthesis are different from that of ammonia decomposition with a smaller hydrogen pressure in the case of ammonia decomposition [20]. Also, promoted Co catalysts are expected to react differently to water impurities than pristine Co catalysts under ammonia decomposition conditions. Despite its significance, water poisoning in the case of ammonia decomposition reaction has been scarcely addressed in scientific literature. In this study, we use theoretical calculations to understand how water reacts on promoted and unpromoted Co catalysts. This investigation aims to provide a clear understanding of the water effect on the ammonia decomposition reaction, which includes: the limit at which water starts to compromise the activity of the catalyst and the potential role of BaO promoter in resisting water poisoning. We present a new microkinetic model for ammonia decomposition that includes the effect of oxygen poisoning due to trace water content in the input gas stream. Understanding the effect of water poisoning provides guidance for developing more stable catalysts and optimizing process conditions, which is critical for commercial operations. 2 Methods 2.1 Density Functional Theory (DFT) methods Spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [21,22]. VASP functionalities were automated using the code from Bhimineni et al. [23]. The projector-augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe core electrons, while valence one electron orbitals were developed in a basis set of plane waves with a 400 eV cutoff energy [24,25]. The Perdew−Burke−Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional in the framework of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed to calculate the electronic structures [26]. Dispersion interactions were included using the DFT-D3 method of Grimme [27,28]. The force convergence threshold was set to 0.03 eV/Å and the dipole correction was applied. The lattice constants for HCP bulk Co with P63/mmc crystallographic symmetry and two Co atoms per unit cell were calculated as a = b = 2.466 Å, c = 3.987 and was optimized using a Monkhorst−Pack k-point mesh of (10 × 10 × 6). The stepped (10 1 ¯ 5) facet was selected because of the presence of the B5 sites which are essential to activate N-N association in the ammonia decomposition reaction [20,29,30]. Our previous study showed that the Ba-based promoter used in decomposing ammonia was likely to be O-bound, therefore, BaO was selected for this study rather than metallic Ba [31]. Literature has established that modeling promoters as single atoms, rather than nanoparticles, provides a computationally feasible and effective approach [20,32–34]. This model has proven effective for the ammonia decomposition reaction, as shown in our previous work [35]. The simplified model isolates the promoter’s role and allows for a clear analysis of its interaction with the surface. Systematic testing was done to determine the optimal position of BaO. BaO was not stable when initially placed on other sites, the structure resorts to the B5 site after optimization, which also agrees with the literature [20,33]. Surfaces were modeled by 4 × 6 supercells and four-atomic-layer slabs [20]. Top views of the studied surfaces are shown in Fig. 1 . The positions of the two topmost layers and the adsorbates were relaxed, and the rest of the layers were fixed to the bulk geometry. Sampling of the Brillouin zone was performed by a (5 × 5 × 1) Monkhorst–Pack grid [36]. Each slab was separated from the next one in the z-direction by a vacuum of 15 Å to eliminate the interaction between them. Transition states were calculated using the climbing image-nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [37] with 8 images. CI-NEB calculations were subsequently converged to low force (0.03 eV/Å) using the Quasi-Newton method. Transition states were verified using vibrational frequency calculations, resulting in a single imaginary frequency along the reaction coordinate. The internal adsorption energy of adsorbates was calculated following equation (1). (1) Δ E adsorption = E adsorbate/surface - E surface - E adsorbate where ΔE adsorption is the adsorption energy, E adsorbate/surface is the total energy of the adsorbates on the surface of the slab, E surface is the energy of the clean slab surface and E adsorbate is the energy of the reference gaseous molecules. The Gibbs free energy for adsorbates on the surface was calculated with the approximation that all degrees of freedom are treated harmonically as shown in equation (2). (2) G = E + E vib + P V - T S where G is Gibbs free energy, E the internal energy, and Evib is the vibrational energy which includes contributions from zero-point energy (ZPE) and thermal excitations at the reaction temperature. The pressure and volume (PV) term is assumed to be negligible. T is the reaction temperature (723.15 K) and S is the entropy including only the vibrational degrees of freedom for the adsorbates. The vibrational frequencies were calculated while keeping the surface fixed and allowing only the adsorbates to relax. All vibrational modes were accounted for in the calculations. For the gas phase molecules, translational, rotational, electronic, and vibrational degrees of freedom were included and calculated according to the ideal-gas limit in the Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) package [38]. 2.2 Microkinetic model The microkinetic model was constructed with no assumption of a rate-determining step based on the ten elementary steps presented in Table 1 . An initial atmospheric pressure was assumed for NH3. The reaction constants of the adsorption, desorption, and surface reaction steps were calculated using the free energy values obtained from DFT calculations. Equations used to calculate the reaction constants are provided in Table S1 . The resulting system of ordinary differential equations was solved till a steady state was reached using the backward-differentiation formulas (BDF) method implemented in the Python package SciPy [39]. The O desorption step was not considered in the system as the desorption of O is very unlikely due to the high energy barrier ∼2 eV. The initial condition assumed zero coverage for all species as the surfaces were considered empty. 3 Results and discussion To understand the stability of H2O and O relative to other adsorbates in the ammonia decomposition reaction, the Gibbs free energies of N, NH3, H, H2O and O on Co and Co-BaO at the reaction temperature were calculated and presented in Fig. 2 . It is observed that the presence of BaO on the Co surface makes the adsorption of O stronger [18]. Unlike the other adsorption energies, the Gibbs free adsorption energy of water is positive and not thermodynamically favored. This suggests that water might be absorbed in a dissociated form rather than in a molecular form. The electronic effects introduced by BaO modify the adsorption energy on the catalyst surface and could explain the difference in *O adsorption strength between Co and Co-BaO. The density of states calculations (DOS) of the 3d orbital of the Co B-type step active sites shows that there is an upward shift of the d-band center with respect to the Fermi level in Co-BaO (−1.10) relative to Co (−1.24) as shown in Fig. S1 (a). Additionally, BaO introduces an electrostatic potential that could influence the adsorption energy as shown in Fig. S1 (b) [35]. Gibbs free energy reaction profiles of water dissociation on Co and Co-BaO at 723.15 K are presented in Fig. 3 . The reaction profiles show that the adsorption of the dissociated form of water (HO*+H) is more stable than the molecular form (H2O). The reaction starts with the adsorption of H2O on a bare surface followed by sequential breaking of OH bonds through two transition states shown as TS1 and TS2. The presence of BaO on the surface is observed to decrease the energy of the transition states. Since the desorption of O2 is very unlikely (∼2 eV desorption energy), O is expected to adsorb on the surface. The gas phase thermodynamics for water splitting at the reaction temperature are presented in Table S3 . It was shown in a previous study that promoted and unpromoted catalysts adsorb H differently [31]. Since H2 is a reducing gas and the main product of the ammonia decomposition reaction, the water effect is expected to change with NH3 conversion (with H2 partial pressure) as the reaction proceeds to generate more H2 [40]. Changing the NH3 pressure or the N2 pressure alone showed no influence on the water dissociation reaction. Surface coverage distributions of reaction species were simulated and presented in Fig. 4 . The pressure of H2 is increased gradually by different factors and the NH3 conversion value that corresponds to that partial pressure of H2 is shown in the upper x-axis of Fig. 4. For both catalysts, the coverage of H2O* and HO* is very small and the main species on the surface are O or H. At the initial pressure of H2, the surface is mostly covered with O and for Co, it is completely poisoned. As the partial pressure of H2 increases, the O coverage decreases, and the H coverage dominates the surface. A detailed investigation about the H coverage effect, was presented in our previous study [31]. However, the key difference is that Co-BaO is more sensitive to H2 pressure as the O coverage decreases to less than 0.05 ML at H2 pressure corresponding to around 0.03 % NH3 conversion, while the O coverage decreases to the same value at around 0.3 % NH3 conversion for Co. This means that the conversion limit for oxygen poisoning is about 10 times higher for Co (0.3 %) than Co-BaO (0.03 %) and less H2 pressure is needed to prevent poisoning when the Co catalyst is doped with BaO. Therefore, the correlation between the thermodynamic binding strength of O as presented in Figs. 2-3 and the kinetics of the reduction reaction is not always straightforward. When studying the full reaction network of NH3 and water decomposition, the applied water pressure was increased to 0.01 bar (1000 Pa). This increase is to allow a clearer investigation of the impact of water. Even though this is not the realistic level of water that is usually found in the industrial feed, the focus of this simulation is to compare and understand how promoted and unpromoted surfaces are oxygenated. Fig. 5 shows O coverage (ML) on the surface as a function of NH3 conversion. At low conversion values, O coverage is high but rapidly decreases as conversion progresses for both surfaces. Nonetheless, the O coverage on Co is approximately ten times higher than that on Co-BaO. This indicates that BaO plays a role in decreasing the O poisoning during the ammonia decomposition reaction. This also shows that the binding energy of O, which was stronger in the case of Co-BaO, is not a complete descriptor on its own, particularly in the context of poisoning. The NH3 conversion value required to prevent catalyst oxidation is low, much lower than the conversion reached in the process. Hence, at first consideration, it may appear that the risk of catalyst oxidation is negligible. However, in industrial flow reactors, the conversion is small at the entrance of the catalyzed section and, as a result, a thin section of the catalyst would be oxidized. The challenge lies in the fact that this oxidation deactivates the catalyst, further reducing the NH3 conversion at the reactor inlet zone. Consequently, the oxidation of the catalyst can propagate along the reactor bed over time. This is why it is critical to develop catalysts with high resistance to oxidation, as shown here in the case of Co-BaO. 4 Conclusion DFT-based microkinetic simulations of the ammonia decomposition reaction and water dissociation were used in this study to understand oxygen poisoning on promoted and unpromoted surfaces. The adsorption of oxygen was stronger on the promoted Co catalyst. The Gibbs free energy reaction profiles showed that the presence of BaO on the surface decreased the energy of the transition states for water dissociation. However, we found that thermodynamic binding energies and reaction rates do not follow the same trend. Co-BaO was more sensitive to H2 pressure than Co. The conversion limit for oxygen poisoning for Co-BaO is lower in comparison to that for Co. This means less H2 pressure is needed to prevent oxygen poisoning when BaO is on the surface during the ammonia decomposition reaction. Therefore, despite the stronger adsorption of oxygen on the Co-BaO surface compared to Co, the reduction rate was observed to be higher on Co-BaO. These observations indicate that binding energy alone does not suffice in evaluating catalytic poisoning, as a thorough understanding requires incorporating the kinetics of the reaction as well. Overall, it is encouraging that the level of NH3 conversion required to prevent catalyst oxidation is low. However, oxidation by trace amounts of water poses a risk in flow reactors because the conversion is minimal at the reactor entrance, making the catalyst prone to oxidation and subsequent deactivation. This oxidized zone can expand over time and compromise the stability of the catalyst. The BaO promoter is shown here to efficiently decrease catalyst oxidation at low NH3 conversion due to the faster reduction of the surface O species by H2. Another approach to prevent catalyst oxidation is to co-feed NH3 with a small fraction of H2. This could improve the stability of the catalyst in flow reactor geometries, but it would decrease the H2 yield. These insights provide a deeper understanding of water-induced catalyst oxidation and pave the way for developing more stable and resistant catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The feedstock of the ammonia decomposition reaction often contains water impurities. Water-induced Co oxidation leads to catalyst deactivation. DFT-based microkinetic simulations of ammonia decomposition and water dissociation reactions are used to understand oxygen poisoning on promoted and unpromoted Co surfaces. Simulations show that catalyst oxidation only occurs at low NH3 conversion and, at higher conversion, the produced H2 reduces the catalyst. Hence, in a typical flow reactor, catalyst oxidation is likely to occur only at the reactor inlet. However, the oxidized zone can slowly propagate along the reactor and impact the catalyst stability. The adsorption of oxygen was stronger on BaO-promoted Co in comparison to pristine Co. However, Co-BaO is more sensitive to H2 pressure and needs a lower ammonia conversion to prevent oxygen poisoning on the surface. This indicates that the BaO promoter plays a role in making the catalyst more resistant to O-induced poisoning during the ammonia decomposition reaction.
